awd_titl_txt: Space Weather Workshop; Boulder, Colorado; April 25–29, 2022
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides partial funding for the Space Weather Workshop to be held in Boulder, Colorado or online in April 2022. The annual Space Weather Workshop, supported by NOAA, NASA, and NSF, has been our nation’s premier meeting on this topic since 1996. It brings together researchers, infrastructure operators, and policymakers to share actionable information on space weather, whose modeling and prediction remains a current challenge for science and societal resilience. 

The Space Weather Workshop highlights the remarkably diverse impacts of space weather on today’s technology including electric power systems, communications, navigation, aviation, and spacecraft operations. It explores recent scientific advances in predicting conditions in the space environment and the breadth of space weather research to operations and operations to research opportunities. The workshop promotes undergraduate and graduate student participation in space weather science and gives them insights into our nation’s space weather priorities, thus developing the next generation of space weather professionals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Space Weather Workshop (SWW) is a premier meeting for the Space Weather community to share information and network with the industry, academia, and government agencies. The meeting is co-sponsored by NOAA, NASA and NSF. As the nation’s leading conference on all issues relating to space weather, the major goals of the April 17-21, 2023 workshop were to:

  • foster communication among researchers, space weather service providers, and users of space weather services
  • address the remarkable diverse impacts of space weather on today’s technology
  • highlight space weather impacts in several areas, including communications, navigation, spacecraft operations, human space exploration, aviation, electric power, and space traffic coordination
  • identify the highest priority needs for operational services that can guide future research
  • identify new high-value research capabilities that can be transitioned into operations
  • provide for significant student participation that will help to develop the next generation of space weather professionals
  • emphasize the benefits of diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) through adhering to those principles in forming an organizing committee and meeting program

The meeting program can be found at NOAA’s Space Weather Prediction Center Website under the Annual Meeting link and going to prior workshops for the 2023 Meeting workshop agenda, or directly to: https://www.swpc.noaa.gov/content/prior-workshops

 As discussed below, the workshop was successful in all of the above goals. It should also be noted that this was the first ever hybrid SWW, following two years of virtual only meetings because of Covid-19. This new format provided an opportunity to benefit once again from in-person discussion and collaboration, but to also be inclusive by providing a virtual option. The virtual option was especially beneficial to students who may have limited travel funding. This meeting was the largest ever in-person SWW. [Registration: 529 attendees (405 in person, 124 virtual) including 56 graduate and undergraduate students (20 in person, 36 virtual).
